Adam Jack wrote:

> My quick eyeballing of the ant code it used arrays of
> testcases and perhaps even it's own runner, which in itself
> (not using the framework just the testcase code) seems a
> shame to me. I'm not saying I'm right, this is just what a quick look
> showed me. 

Mhh, I don't know why the Ant developers decided to not use the
TestSuite class. I do know that there are collectors out there which do.

> I guess there is a constant tussle between a pure framework
> and use case, but this feels like some sort of software
> evolution to me. I used to use suites, I used to use the
> Swing Runner, but now I use Eclipse and I'll never go back.

I just tried the testcase collector of Eclipse and found that it simply
is to slow for me. I am working on projects consisting of 1000+ classes
and I don't want to wait several seconds every time I start the tests. I
guess it would be similar for Ant - our Ant builds already take far too
long, using a collector probably wouldn't improve the situation.

> When does the new user case become the norm? When does the
> framework change to satisfy the new users?

I still don't understand why the framework needs to change. Ant, Eclipse
and other projects show very well that you can do what you want without
needing to change the framework.

Regards, Ilja
